subject: Re: [junit] Programmer Tests and the Database
msgSnippet: So said  Curt Sampson  on  2/13/2003 -------------------- ... test ... the ... less ... statement ... When did I say that? I said -- and I usually say, so
messageBody:
So said Curt Sampson on 2/13/2003 --------------------

>On Mon, 10 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>> If I change the SQL statements, then I test the new statements as
>> needed. That's why I put them in one place, to make them easier to
test
>> all at once and in isolation from the rest of the system.
>
>*Shrug*. So basically, you're saying you don't want to test that the
>Java code you write is using the SQL correctly, and interpreting the
>results correctly. That's your call, I guess, but you're going to be
the
>one that loses when someone changes an SQL statement to return one
less
>parameter, because you'll never know that the class using that
statement
>now can't read the ResultSet.

When did I say that?

I said -- and I usually say, so that's how I know I said it -- that I
test two basic things:

1. Is my SQL statement correct?
2. Can I make objects out of ResultSets?

To clarify, this is what I do in my Programmer Tests.

I will almost certainly have Customer Tests that verify that the thing
works all together, and if I don't, then I may write Integration Tests
to handle the parts of the database integration that I'm unsure about.

But for Programmer Tests, I want to test that I get the SQL statement
right and that I interact with ResultSets correctly. The rest just
seems to be testing the database or JDBC, and I'm interested in
neither.

Perhaps some context was lost along the way. That happens in e-mail...
